Experiment_description: The experiments conducted in this stage implement a Bag-of-Tokens model with a feed-forward network to process and classify glyphs. Both nodes focus on establishing a robust baseline using cross-entropy loss for training on both real and synthetic datasets.
Significance: These experiments are significant as they establish a foundational pipeline for glyph processing, crucial for future enhancements in glyph clustering techniques. The consistency and robustness of the baseline model are necessary for ensuring reliable performance benchmarks against which future innovations can be compared.
Description: The experiments involved treating each glyph as a token and vectorizing sequences using a Bag-of-Tokens model, followed by training a small two-layer feed-forward network optimized for GPU usage. Both nodes aim to develop a foundational baseline, focusing on reproducibility and robustness, with metrics such as accuracy, Color-Weighted Accuracy, Shape-Weighted Accuracy, and Complexity-Weighted Accuracy reported for both validation and test datasets.

List_of_included_plots.description: This plot shows the cross-entropy loss for both training and validation over five epochs.
List_of_included_plots.analysis: The plot indicates steady learning and convergence of the model, with both training and validation losses decreasing, suggesting effective generalization.

List_of_included_plots.description: This plot depicts the performance of the model on various metrics over five epochs.
List_of_included_plots.analysis: The metrics plateau early, suggesting that the model reaches optimal performance quickly, but differences between validation and test performance indicate room for improvement.

List_of_included_plots.description: This confusion matrix shows the model's performance on the test set.
List_of_included_plots.analysis: The confusion matrix reveals areas for improvement in reducing false positives and negatives, which are critical for enhancing classification accuracy.

Key_numerical_results.analysis: Indicates effective model training with convergence.
Low validation loss suggests good generalization.
High validation accuracy reflects strong model performance on validation data.
Test accuracy is notably lower than validation accuracy, indicating a gap in performance on unseen data.
Similar effective training and convergence as seen in the other node.
